moves.1. e4: The opening is a Sicilian Najdorf, so annotations will come later.
moves.1... c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6: Black decides to expand on the kingside.
Black has two bishops, so White is attempting to force a trade of minor pieces. But Topalov knew that what was most important here were squares on the d-file. 16...e5 would weaken the d5-square. This is why he played...
moves.16... Be5: (!) Doubled pawns for Black would dominate the d-file, benficial to him.
moves.17. Qd2 Qf6: White now didn't choose 18.Rad1 Bxd4+ or 18...Qf4 19.Qxf4 gxf4 since this endgame is weaker.
moves.18. Bxe5 dxe5: (!) White's rooks can't be opened up any more. Black has all trgets covered, whereas White has weaknesses.
moves.19. a4: (?) Here, 19.Qd6! Would provoke 19...Rd8 20.Qc5... Meaning Black's king needs to find a safe square AND connect rooks. This would cause temporary disarray for Black.
moves.22. Qxf4 gxf4: (!) White can regroup his knight with Nc3-a2-b4. However he hs targets at g2 and f3, which could falter soon with ...f5
moves.23. Rfd1 h4 24. Rxd8+ Rxd8 25. Rd1 Rc8: (!) Topalov keeps his rook to attack g2 and c2.
moves.31. Ke2 Be8: (!) Black's bishop can join the attack. One variation is 32.c4 Bh5+ 33.Kf1 Rd8 34.Rxd8 Kxd8 35.Nd3 Bd1! If 33.Ke1... Then 33...Rd8 34.Rxd8 Kxd8 35.Nd3 Bg6.
moves.35. gxh3 Rg1+ 36. Kb2 Bf3 37. Nxe5 Bxe4: The h-pawns are fodder for Black's pieces.
moves.40... Kg4 41. h5 f3 42. h6 Kf4 43. Nd2 R: Topalov wins after a beautiful display of positional prowess.
